DataElement.preferredName: Stage Prognostic Factor Collaborative Staging Metastasis Site Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Identifies the distant site(s) of metastatic involvement at time of diagnosis.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Stage Prognostic Factor Collaborative Staging Metastasis Site
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Belongs to the set of Collaborative Staging (CS) data items and is part of the detailed site-specific codes for anatomic EOD effective with 2004 diagnosis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.:The general personal and health characteristics that have a bearing on the course of a disease and its eventual outcome.

Concepts.definition: The extent of a cancer in the body.
The general personal and health characteristics that have a bearing on the course of a disease and its eventual outcome.

Property.preferredDefinition: A coding system for staging of cancer bringing together the principles of Summary Stage, the TNM categories and stage groupings, and the SEER Extent of Disease (EOD) coding structure, creating a carefully selected set of data items that describe how far a cancer has spread at the time of diagnosis. The Collaborative Staging System uses a modified EOD coding system, a five-field, 10 digit system: tumor size (3 digits), extension of the primary tumor (2 digits), regional lymph node involvement (highest specific lymph node chain involved by tumor) (1 digit), the number of pathologically reviewed regional lymph nodes that are positive (2 digits), and the number of pathologically examined regional lymph nodes (2 digits).:Cancer that has spread from the organ in which it first appeared to another organ. For example, breast cancer cells may spread (metastasize) to the lungs and cause the growth of a new tumor. When this happens, the disease is called metastatic breast cancer.:Position in relation to the surroundings.

Concepts.definition: A coding system for staging of cancer bringing together the principles of Summary Stage, the TNM categories and stage groupings, and the SEER Extent of Disease (EOD) coding structure, creating a carefully selected set of data items that describe how far a cancer has spread at the time of diagnosis. The Collaborative Staging System uses a modified EOD coding system, a five-field, 10 digit system: tumor size (3 digits), extension of the primary tumor (2 digits), regional lymph node involvement (highest specific lymph node chain involved by tumor) (1 digit), the number of pathologically reviewed regional lymph nodes that are positive (2 digits), and the number of pathologically examined regional lymph nodes (2 digits).

The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor.
A position in relation to its surroundings.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Top level term which includes Biological Markers, Risk Factors, and Prognostic Factors.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A coding system for staging of cancer bringing together the principles of Summary Stage, the TNM categories and stage groupings, and the SEER Extent of Disease (EOD) coding structure, creating a carefully selected set of data items that describe how far a cancer has spread at the time of diagnosis. The Collaborative Staging System uses a modified EOD coding system, a five-field, 10 digit system: tumor size (3 digits), extension of the primary tumor (2 digits), regional lymph node involvement (highest specific lymph node chain involved by tumor) (1 digit), the number of pathologically reviewed regional lymph nodes that are positive (2 digits), and the number of pathologically examined regional lymph nodes (2 digits)._Cancer that has spread from the organ in which it first appeared to another organ. For example, breast cancer cells may spread (metastasize) to the lungs and cause the growth of a new tumor. When this happens, the disease is called metastatic breast cancer._Position in relation to the surroundings._A system of numbered categories for representation of data. [Explanatory Comment: See the Collabortive Staging Manual and Coding Instructions, Version 1.0 for site-specifc codes and coding rules.]

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

The Collaborative Staging System uses a modified EOD coding system, a five-field, 10 digit system: tumor size (3 digits), extension of the primary tumor (2 digits), regional lymph node involvement (highest specific lymph node chain involved by tumor) (1 digit), the number of pathologically reviewed regional lymph nodes that are positive (2 digits), and the number of pathologically examined regional lymph nodes (2 digits).:Cancer that has spread from the organ in which it first appeared to another organ. Concepts.definition: A coding system for staging of cancer bringing together the principles of Summary Stage, the TNM categories and stage groupings, and the SEER Extent of Disease (EOD) coding structure, creating a carefully selected set of data items that describe how far a cancer has spread at the time of diagnosis. The Collaborative Staging System uses a modified EOD coding system, a five-field, 10 digit system: tumor size (3 digits), extension of the primary tumor (2 digits), regional lymph node involvement (highest specific lymph node chain involved by tumor) (1 digit), the number of pathologically reviewed regional lymph nodes that are positive (2 digits), and the number of pathologically examined regional lymph nodes (2 digits).

The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor.
A position in relation to its surroundings.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

ClassificationSchemes.longName: Division of Cancer Control and Population Sciences

ReferenceDocuments.name: CS Mets at DX Description
ReferenceDocuments.description: This modification for CS is collapsible into AJCC M code according to the sixth edition of AJCC Cancer Staging Manual. Site-specific codes provide extensive detail describing disease extent. CS Mets at DX is used to derive the Derived AJCC M [2980], Derived AJCC Stage Group [3000], Derived SS1977 [3010], and Derived SS2000 [3020]

ReferenceDocuments.name: Collaborative Staging (CS) Reference Manuals
ReferenceDocuments.description: The Collaborative Stage Data Collection System (CS) Web pages serve as the main repository for CS-related items including coding instructions, software, and education and training resources for cancer registrars and cancer registry software vendors

ReferenceDocuments.name: SEER Coding and Staging Manuals
ReferenceDocuments.description: Coding and Staging Manuals for the Surivellance Epidemiology and End Results Program

ReferenceDocuments.name: AJCC Cancer Staging Manual
ReferenceDocuments.description: See the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual, current edition, for site-specific categories for the TNM elements and stage groups.

ReferenceDocuments.name: NAACCR 12.1, Data Stds/Dict.
ReferenceDocuments.description: For additional details see NAACCR, Standards for Cancer Registries Volume II, Version 12.1 Data Standards and Data Dictionary (6/2010)

ReferenceDocuments.name: NAACCR 16, Data Stds/Dict.
ReferenceDocuments.description: For additional details see NAACCR, Standards for Cancer Registries Volume II, Version 16 Data Standards and Data Dictionary (01/2016)
